newsitem.title: FINLAND: NOKIA TUGS AS THIN HELSINKI FLOATS TO NEW RECORDS.
newsitem.headline: NOKIA TUGS AS THIN HELSINKI FLOATS TO NEW RECORDS.

text.p: Shares wafted in thin trade to
a new all-time high close on the main indices on Monday, with
the strong dollar helping Nokia and forestries and financials
adding a push on an otherwise mixed market, brokers said.
The FOX index gained 0.88 percent to a life-high 1,172.31,
scraping past its previous July 9 peak by four points, while the
all-share HEX rose 0.97 percent to a record 3,417.01 points. The
459 million markka volume was meagre against recent levels.
"This looks fairly strong, but it all depends on how the
U.S. market performs," one broker said, while others said a
higher open on Wall Street for Nokia pointed to further upside.
With many domestic operators on summer holiday, brokers
said a scarcity of sellers in combination with a normal level
of overseas demand drove prices higher.
Nokia closed 9.20 markka higher at 428.20, coming off an
intraday high of 431.00 which was just a few markka short of its
all-time high 433.00 set last week.
Nokia's two shares together added more than five points to
the FOX index's 10 point gains.
The dollar-markka exchange rate punched briefly through 5.3
and helped Nokia and forestries, in particular, brokers said.
UPM-Kymmene closed 0.50 higher at 135.00 in fair volume.
Enso gained 0.40 markka to 50.90, stopping just
short of its 51.00 all-time high.
Pulp prices seemed to be firming, and a strike that began
Monday at major Canadian producer Fletcher Challenge
could support prices further by curbing supply, brokers said.
Finnish pulp derivatives exchange SOPI put the price of
northern bleached softwood pulp at $573.88 per tonne, up from
$572.30 last week.
Merita rose 0.40 markka to end at 20.30 after touching an
all-time high 20.40 in sturdy 28 million markka volume. It was
the first time the stock closed above 20.00 markka.
Software and data services group TT Tieto rose sharply in
brisk overseas and domestic demand, brokers said. It rose 32.00
markka, or more than seven percent, to 470.00, just one markka
off its all-time high 471.00.
Brokers said TT Tieto mirrored strength in Swedish software
maker WM-Data , though they said there did not seem to
be concrete connection between the gains in the two shares.
"The (data processing) sector has risen in Sweden, and
that's reflected here," one broker said. Others pointed to
recent gains in U.S. technology stocks as a possible explanation
for TT's rise.
--Helsinki newsroom +358-0-6805 0235
